. However, due to the dual operating nature of PHEV vehicles, one can expect
ities for these vehicles will lie between those of their ICEV and

Currently, BEVs have higher manufacturing emissions than equivalently sized ICEVs, with median
fuelled counterparts. These higher production emissions of BEVs are largely attributed to the battery
pack manufacturing and to the additional power electronics required. As manufacturing
capacity utilization improve and globalizes to regions with low
manufacturing emissions will likely decrease. Due to the higher energy efficiency of the electric
powertrain, BEVs may compensate for these higher pr
oduction emissions in the driving phase
the mitigation ability of this technology relative to ICEVs is highly dependent on the
electricity mix used to charge the vehicle. As a consequence of the variety of energy sources available
BEVs have a wide range of potential average life cycle impacts, ranging between 60 and
with electricity generated from wind and coal, respectively. The ability to achieve
large carbon reductions via vehicle electrification is thus highl
y dependent on the generation of low
carbon electricity, with the greatest mitigation effects achieved when charging the battery with low
carbon electricity. The literature suggests that current BEVs, if manufactured on low carbon electricity
erated on low carbon electricity would
. This value suggests a reduction potential of around
85% compared to similarly sized fossil fuel vehicles (median values). Furthermore, BEVs have a co
benefit of reducing local air polluta
nts that are responsible for human health complications, particularly
FCVs have higher production emissions than similarly sized ICEVs and BEVs,
generating on average approximately 15 t CO
eq/vehicle. As with BEVs, the life cycle impacts of
FCVs are highly dependent on the fuel chain. To date, the most common method of
production is steam methane reforming from natural gas
Current literature covering life cycle impacts of the FCVs show that vehicles fuelled with
produced from steam methane reforming through natural gas offer
little or no mitigation potential over
fuel chains vary widely in carbon intensity, depending on the
synthesis method and the energy source used (electrolysis or steam methane reforming; fossil fuels vs.

Vehicle size trends and implications on the fuel efficiency of LDVs
On a global scale, SUV sales have been constantly growing in the last decade, with
39% of the vehicles sold in 2018 being SUVs
, it may result in higher overall emissions from the LDV fleet
